Dying Light 2 Stay Human: Reloaded Edition is the definitive version of Techland’s open-world action survival game. It includes all major updates, balance fixes, new content, and system overhauls released since the original 2022 launch. This version aims to deliver the most complete and stable experience for both new players and returning fans.

The core gameplay remains centered on fast parkour traversal and brutal melee combat. Players navigate a vast post-apocalyptic city filled with infected and hostile survivors, using agility and improvisation to survive. RPG progression remains a key feature—skills, gear, and moral decisions continue to shape both the protagonist and the world around him.

The “Reloaded” edition introduces significant improvements, most notably the long-awaited addition of firearms. Pistols, rifles, and new ammunition types enhance combat variety, allowing smoother transitions between melee and ranged play. Techland also rebalanced enemy encounters, skill trees, and loot drops, making progression more rewarding and less repetitive.

Visually, the game still impresses. The lighting, environmental detail, and day–night cycle remain among the best in open-world design. Performance on current consoles and PCs is mostly stable, though minor bugs and animation quirks persist. The improved optimization makes exploration and combat feel smoother than before.

Multiplayer and co-op modes have also been refined. Teaming up with friends to clear infected nests, parkour across rooftops, or tackle story missions adds longevity and replay value. Cross-play and better network stability make cooperative play far more enjoyable than in early versions.

Content-wise, Reloaded Edition consolidates previous DLC and seasonal events, while expanding on side missions and world activities. Combined with improved AI and combat responsiveness, it feels more cohesive and polished overall. For returning players, it’s a strong reason to revisit; for newcomers, it’s the best way to start.

Overall, Dying Light 2 Stay Human: Reloaded Edition transforms a solid but flawed game into a robust, complete package. Its refined systems, new weapons, and technical upgrades finally realize the game’s potential. While a few rough edges remain, this is easily the definitive version—a satisfying blend of parkour freedom, visceral combat, and post-apocalyptic atmosphere.

Long-awaited sequel to the beloved 2015 parkour–zombie hybrid. It expands the original’s formula with a larger world, deeper RPG systems, and a strong emphasis on player choice. While not without flaws, it delivers memorable moments, exhilarating movement, and one of the most atmospheric open-world settings in modern games.

Story & Characters

You play as Aiden Caldwell, a wandering Pilgrim searching for his lost sister in a world devastated by the virus. The story takes place in Villedor, a massive European-inspired city filled with factions, political tensions, and survivors fighting for control.

The narrative is more ambitious than in the first game. Choices matter and can shape the entire city—opening new areas, changing water access, or determining which faction controls a district. While not every choice feels impactful, the major ones genuinely change how the world reacts.

Character writing is mixed but improved from the original. Aiden is more expressive than Crane, and characters like Lawan stand out with emotional depth. However, some story beats feel rushed or underdeveloped.

Gameplay & Combat

The parkour system is significantly expanded—smoother, faster, and more expressive. Climbing buildings, sprinting across rooftops, and chaining moves together feels fluid and incredibly satisfying. Once you unlock a few upgrades, movement becomes almost addictive.

Combat leans heavily into melee. The weapons feel weighty, brutal, and impactful, with satisfying animations and dismemberment. The special infected create tense encounters, and nighttime is still dangerous—but less terrifying than in the original.

Some enemies sponge hits, especially early on, but upgrading your skills and gear fixes this later in the game.

World & Atmosphere

Villedor is the game’s crown jewel. The vertical design is fantastic—lower streets dark, hostile, and filled with infected; rooftops alive with human activity, greenery, and sunlight. It creates a genuine “two worlds” feeling.

The game’s day–night cycle completely changes gameplay. Daytime feels like a typical open-world RPG, but nights are tense and risky, with infected flooding the streets and chases escalating quickly.

Progression & RPG Systems

The game leans more into RPG elements: Gear with rarity levels, weapon durability, skill trees for parkour and combat, crafting and modding, faction rewards for city zones. Progression feels rewarding, but some systems—like gear scaling—can make earlier weapons feel irrelevant too quickly.

Issues & Criticisms

Story pacing is inconsistent.
Some dialogue choices feel meaningless.
Durability can feel restrictive early on.
Nighttime is less scary and intense than the original.

But despite the flaws, the core gameplay remains excellent.

Verdict

Dying Light 2 is a big, bold sequel that gets the most important parts right: parkour, city design, atmosphere, and satisfying combat. While the story and progression systems don’t always hit the mark, the moment-to-moment gameplay is so fun that the imperfections fade quickly.

It’s not as groundbreaking as the original Dying Light, but it’s still one of the best open-world action games in recent years.

Rating: 8.5/10

I absolutely adore Dying Light 2! This game took everything I loved about the first one and made it even better. I went into Dying Light 2 without huge expectations, but the game absolutely won me over. It’s one of those titles that pulls you in slowly and then suddenly you realize you’ve been playing for hours without noticing the time. The overall atmosphere, the movement, and the world design come together surprisingly well.

Parkour and movement are easily the strongest parts of the game. The flow of running, jumping, grabbing ledges, sprinting across rooftops, and chaining moves together feels incredibly smooth. Once you get a few upgrades, moving around the city becomes almost addictive. It’s rare for a game to make traversal itself this fun.

The combat is also satisfying. It’s rough, heavy, and brutal in a good way. Every hit feels solid, and the melee-focused style fits the world perfectly. Modded weapons, elemental effects, and the general chaos of fighting infected or human enemies keep things from feeling repetitive..

The story surprised me more than I expected. It’s not perfect, but I genuinely got invested in the characters. People like Hakon and Lawan give the game personality, and even when their actions frustrate you, they stay interesting. Some of the choices actually made me think for a minute before deciding. The decisions don’t always change the world dramatically, but they do affect the emotional weight of the story, and that was enough to keep me hooked.

The world-building is another strong point. Villedor feels alive despite being broken. The difference between daytime exploration and nighttime danger is well-executed. During the day, you’re climbing buildings and looting freely. At night, the tension rises, chases get intense, and UV lights suddenly become the most comforting thing in the world. It creates a good balance between freedom and fear.

Of course, the game has flaws. Some side missions are repetitive, certain choices don’t matter as much as they should, and the pacing can be uneven in places. There are still a few bugs here and there, though nothing that ruined the experience for me.

Overall, I genuinely enjoyed Dying Light 2 far more than I expected. It delivers great movement, fun combat, an atmospheric world, and characters that keep the story engaging. For anyone who likes open-world games with a focus on parkour, survival, and character-driven storytelling, this one is absolutely worth playing.

Got this game after finally upgrading from my potato laptop to a mid range gaming PC. The game has its pros and cons, and i'll list them down below. Be warned that these is based on my experience and what i felt while playing, and comparing this to the first game. 

Pros:
- A lot more parkour variations compared to the first game. The only downside i have is the delay in some of the skills activating and sometimes not activating. The delay are from the sliding skill and the paraglider. Both have a delay when trying to trigger. Like you need to hold it for a second or two before you begin sliding or taking out the paraglider.

- Smooth combat. Weapon handling feels good. The devs implemented weapon range. Meaning each type of weapon has its own range. Like knives needing you to be closer to the enemy, while two handed weapons give you more distance.

- Beautiful scenery. You get to experience old architecture and new ones in two distinct maps. 

- Quite a variety of weapons compared to the first game. And each has its own benefits. Like to handed axe power strike will slash, While a polearm will pierce on power strike.

- Gun play is nice. Despite the annoyance of not allowing overlapping buttons for Aiming Down Sight, the gunplay is smooth. The guns feel heavy when you're moving, shooting, and even when reloading. The reloading animations are also very nice.

- Detailed enemy hitbox. Meaning you have a lot of areas to damage. You can cut off hands. arms, heads. split the body in half, etc. Just that it makes it slightly difficult to get that nice decapitation.

Cons:
- Compared to the first game, the Bloody Ties DLC is crap imo. Its just basically a set of challenges that has a timer, forced equipment, and boss enemies that is tanky. Im fine with forced equipment, but making the enemies almost impervious to my parkour combats skills that i worked hard to get, plus the small arena, just makes the whole experience being annoying rather than fun. 

- Main Story is kinda dull. I wasnt able to immerse myself into it. Despite my first playthrough, halfway through the game and almost 100 hours in, i find myself fast reading and skipping most of the dialogue.

- Main Story boss has plot. We literally took down hordes of enemies, but everytime we come across him we either kept getting thrown around or our "infection" triggers which causes our character to spasm and blackout.

- Im sure its for optimisation, but there is a lot of reused assets. Especially seen in the interior section of buildings. This ruins most of the immersion, since youd expect the layout of a pharmacy and a convenience store to be different, but no. The inside are the same. You expect the safehouses for each area, or at least between Old Villador and the Central Loop, to be different. But nope. Its all the same. 

- Armour from vendors are too expensive. A unique purple armour piece costs 65k at max level 9. Unless you havent been upgrading, repairing or buying anything, youll unlikely to have that much money. 

- Knuckle Dusters and Knives are so rare in the vendor or loot pool. Knuckle Dusters in vendors ive only seen it thrice, not once for knives. And knive loot drops only four times and non for knuckle dusters. This is after 130 hours of gameplay.

- DLC armour pieces are trash. The main armour itself is good. But the prefixes stay at level 1. Meaning youd be better off using base game armour.

- A lot of combat skills. But most youll unlikely to use. Because a lot of them are situational. Remember the spinning 360 degree strike in the first game? Its also in this game. But, unlike the first game where its easy to trigger, in this game you have to charge your power strike and then press CapsLock. Of which your power strike can be interrupted by attacks.

- In Nightmare mod, you cant tell the time. Outside of hearing the sound cues for going into night time and the sun setting. They shouldve made the character model wear a watch like the first game. Where preparing to throw the weapon allowed you to look at the watch on the character's wrist. The also shouldve made the Infection Monitor worn backwards, towards the player. So you can see it without needing to rely on the hud. Why? Because like the watch to tell time in the first game, its dynamic. Meaning the longer you spend in the dark, the more the infection takes over, the Infection Monitor bar will drop from green to red. You can see this when equipping the knife.

- No faction gear or outfit. Sure you can say we have the Survivor faction gear because they mostly wear casual clothes. But there is no faction gear for the PK faction available for the player to use. The only side faction that actually gave you clothing, or outfit, based on their faction is the Courier Guild. Theyll give you two outfits based on the missions you complete for the guild.

Dying Light 2 is a game of brilliant, exhausting contradictions. It’s a parkour sandbox that feels more natural than breathing, yet its story often feels like a lead weight tied to your ankles. The sheer kinetic joy of scrambling up skyscrapers, kicking zombies off rooftops, and gliding through a gorgeously decaying European city is a high that the game’s narrative constantly tries to sabotage.

The world itself is the star. The day/night cycle isn’t a gimmick; it’s a fundamental shift in gameplay philosophy. Daylight is for methodical exploration and clearing out infested nests, while the night is a terrifying, pulse-pounding race for survival against Volatiles that feel genuinely threatening. This dynamic is masterful.

Where it stumbles is in its choices. The promise that your decisions will radically reshape the city is overstated. You’re mostly just changing the color of the flag on a building and which faction of forgettable NPCs gives you quests. The main story is a slog of betrayals and McGuffins that fails to land any emotional punches, making you wish you could just ignore it all and focus on the sublime movement mechanics.

Ultimately, Dying Light 2 is a game you play for the journey, not the destination. It’s a first-person platformer with a combat system and a forgettable story duct-taped to the side. If you can tolerate a narrative that actively resists being engaging, the physical experience of navigating its world is absolutely top-tier. Dying Light 2 is an outstanding open-world action game that successfully blends intense parkour movement, brutal combat, and meaningful player choices into a thrilling post-apocalyptic experience. That said, while the game offers well-designed individual missions and side quests, it would be amazing to see a completely new main story and an entirely new map added in the future. A fresh setting with new characters and conflicts could greatly expand the longevity of the game. Additionally, an upgrade and expansion of the character skill system would be a welcome improvement, giving players even more freedom to customize their playstyle and evolve their hero in new ways.

Overall, Dying Light 2 is a fantastic sequel that delivers thrilling parkour, intense combat, and a gripping world. With a new story, a new map, and deeper skill upgrades in future content, it has the potential to become an even greater masterpiece.

I went into Dying Light 2 Stay Human expecting more of the same parkour-and-zombies formula from the first game, but it ended up surprising me in a lot of good ways. The parkour system is easily the highlight here—once you unlock a few skills, moving across rooftops feels incredibly smooth and addictive. There were plenty of moments where I caught myself just running around for fun instead of doing the next quest.

Combat takes a bit to grow on you, but once the upgrades kick in, it becomes way more satisfying. Smacking infected off rooftops never gets old, and the nighttime chases still deliver that adrenaline rush the series is known for. The city itself has a great atmosphere too; Villedor feels alive, messy, and believable, with each district having its own style and mood.

The story isn’t perfect—some characters hit harder than others—but the choices you make actually matter more than I expected. Seeing districts change depending on who you support adds a nice sense of consequence.

Performance-wise, the game has improved a lot since launch. Fewer bugs, smoother framerate, and co-op is much more stable now. If you played early and bounced off, it’s worth giving it another shot.

Overall, Dying Light 2 Stay Human isn’t flawless, but it delivers a fun world to explore, tense nights, and some of the best movement in any open-world game. If you enjoy parkour, scavenging, and making choices that shape your world, it’s absolutely worth playing.

I have been a die-hard fan of the first Dying Light since its release, and it has been one of my favorite story-based zombie games of all time, up there with the tippy top of that list, The Last of Us. I absolutely adore it. I bought the second game on release on my Xbox, and maybe got an hour of time into it before I was disinterested and moved on. 

Now a couple years later, I've thought back to that older time and wondered why I never put more time into it. I bought it and the first game here on steam like a year ago, and since then, the second game has just been rotting in my library. I figured since I had some time on my hands, I'd put more time and energy into it.

Never before have I been so incredibly disappointed in a sequel to a game I've loved.

A lot of my gripes are very nitpicky, i.e. things you wouldn't really notice or think about if you weren't REALLY paying attention. But with me being older, I'm able to notice flaws a lot more than I used to, no matter how small, and my tolerance for such flaws has diminished alongside that. So, I'd like to put my thoughts down and really talk about why I dislike this game, because in all reality, I feel like I do in fact enjoy it, but it feels held back by a lot of qualities. Most of my gripes come from the fact that I adore the first game, so a lot of the things I don't like here stem from the fact that it's a downgrade of major capacity.

The first thing I noticed, worldbuilding design. In the first game, you are taught how to make a medkit while healing an injured person right in front of you. You subconsciously associate it with something that could heal, YOU. Instead here, you are taught how to make a medkit, for the sake of teaching you how to make a medkit. You don't even need to heal at that point, no dialogue excuse of "oh gosh i'm injured, i should make a medkit".

On top of that, there are things in the prologue home that irked me immediately. In the first game, no piece of dialogue exists without purpose. Everything that everyone says, is designed with a reward in mind, whether it be mission completion, story progression, etc etc. In the second game, Aiden looks at a painting and says, "this is what qualified as art? weirdos". This isn't Undertale, or some Telltale ass interaction game where every piece of furniture has a text box. This is Dying Light, and the Dying Light that I thought I knew doesn't just quip for the sake of a small laugh. I get the need to add dialogue to add personality to your characters, but there are better ways to do it. Take how The Last of Us did it, turn it into a dialogue interaction between to characters, or give an insight to your character's thinking. 

On top of all of that, a lot of the dialogue in this game doesn't mesh well together. Person A starts and finishes their sentence, then Person B starts and finishes their sentence. It feels like the game is waiting for each person to say their piece. Now, think back to the end of Dying Light 1, when Crane and Rais are having their final exchange. The dialogue flows, it's bounces between both in rhythm, and Crane even cuts Rais off at one point, as well as the GRE later in that same cutscene. It feels real, like a genuine conversation. But to this game, it's like the game is checking to see if "diagolue_1" is finished so it can start "dialogue_2", instead of it all being a part of the same mp4 if that makes sense.

Speaking of dialogue, please explain to me why they had to find the one voice actor on the planet that sounded the closest to Roger Smith? If you're gonna reuse a voice actor for a different character, which even on its on is lazy on the front of it, REUSE THE VOICE ACTOR. It took more work to find Jonah Scott than it could've to just renew Roger's contract.

Next up, the motion capture and camera control in cutscenes, in tandem with cutscene pacing. Think back to the first game, back when you meet Rahim in the Tower. His mo-cap feels alive, more than just a character in a video game, and the camera in those cutscenes really do feel like I'm seeing it from Crane's perspective. Meanwhile here, the mo-cap moves for the sake of moving, just to fake showing that these characters are supposedly alive. It feels like an older RPG where NPC's cycle through idle animations, instead of them moving like real people. The camera is taken up by their entire silhouette and moving the camera does not feel nearly as smooth as it did prior.

Keep in mind, as negative as I'm being, all of these aspects fail as being a sequel to an already incredible experience. Most of the game is actually fun to play, the minute to minute I mean. I like how they changed the quests to include more nighttime segments, I like how parrying and blocking feels. I'm not completely dunking on this for being awful, because it's not all that.

Anyways, the crux of why I'm writing this at 4hrs playtime: I got into the metro tunnels, getting to the end of what I assumed to be the first act of the game. I walked up to a door, game crash. No biggie, game crashes occasionally happen even to the monsters of the industry. I boot it up, crashes on file load. I boot it up again, it crashes at a different door. I boot it up, AGAIN, and it crashes before I even start the dialogue prior to either door. I have one of the best PC's money can buy, graphics should not be the issue. But even if it was, that seems like such an obvious crash that testers should've noticed.

I do like this game, at the very least, I want to. But to love games to their fullest, I need to criticize them to see them in their best light, so they could be improved for the future, or at the very least not let those mistakes happen again. With most of the issues I described, this feels like a live-service mmo, and it should not feel this way. This should feel like Dying Light 2.
